{"post_stream":{"posts":[{"id":3164592,"name":"Elliot Scher","username":"Gandagorn","avatar_template":"/user_avatar/www.chiefdelphi.com/gandagorn/{size}/267112_2.png","created_at":"2023-03-14T17:35:38.907Z","cooked":"

This is a thread I created earlier in the season: ADIS16470_IMUSim not turning in autonomous

essentially, the robot, in a pathweaver autonomous mode, would follow the x component of the path, but not the y component as shown in the video in the other thread.

Has anyone had any luck with using pathweaver with an adis16470 IMU?

Here’s my code if it helps: Files · Latest · Elliot Scher / 2815 Robot 2023 · GitLab

Thanks!!

Why are you negating and modding the gyro angle by 360?

    public double getHeading() {
        return -m_IMU.getAngle() % 360;
    }

I also wonder about your mounting orientation when I see another method also using the IMU yaw, but the method has pitch in the name.

    public double getRobotPitch() {
        return m_IMU.getAngle();
    }

I would start by verifying odometry. Put the odometry pose on your dashboard and push the robot around.

","post_number":2,"post_type":1,"posts_count":5,"updated_at":"2023-03-14T18:25:02.955Z","reply_count":1,"reply_to_post_number":null,"quote_count":0,"incoming_link_count":0,"reads":75,"readers_count":74,"score":20.0,"yours":false,"topic_id":430262,"topic_slug":"has-anyone-had-any-luck-with-turning-in-a-pathweaver-autonomous-with-adis16470","display_username":"Andy Gasser","primary_group_name":null,"flair_name":null,"flair_url":null,"flair_bg_color":null,"flair_color":null,"flair_group_id":null,"badges_granted":[],"version":1,"can_edit":false,"can_delete":false,"can_recover":false,"can_see_hidden_post":true,"can_wiki":false,"read":true,"user_title":"","bookmarked":false,"actions_summary":[],"moderator":false,"admin":false,"staff":false,"user_id":44380,"hidden":false,"trust_level":2,"deleted_at":null,"user_deleted":false,"edit_reason":null,"can_view_edit_history":true,"wiki":false,"user_custom_fields":{"user_field_4":"7028 - Java Programming Mentor"},"post_url":"/t/has-anyone-had-any-luck-with-turning-in-a-pathweaver-autonomous-with-adis16470/430262/2","custom_user_title":"7028 - Java Programming Mentor","reactions":[],"current_user_reaction":null,"reaction_users_count":0,"current_user_used_main_reaction":false,"can_accept_answer":false,"can_unaccept_answer":false,"accepted_answer":false,"topic_accepted_answer":null},{"id":3165100,"name":"Elliot Scher","username":"Gandagorn","avatar_template":"/user_avatar/www.chiefdelphi.com/gandagorn/{size}/267112_2.png","created_at":"2023-03-15T11:03:51.024Z","cooked":"

for the getHeading() method, the IMU is CCW positive so negating it allows the value to increase as it turns clockwise. Modding it by 360 makes sure that the robot is always at an angle between 0 and 360. Our roborio is mounted vertically so the yaw axis is actually the pitch axis. When I get back into our shop I will check the odometry. Thanks!

","post_number":3,"post_type":1,"posts_count":5,"updated_at":"2023-03-15T11:18:07.258Z","reply_count":1,"reply_to_post_number":2,"quote_count":0,"incoming_link_count":0,"reads":50,"readers_count":49,"score":15.0,"yours":false,"topic_id":430262,"topic_slug":"has-anyone-had-any-luck-with-turning-in-a-pathweaver-autonomous-with-adis16470","display_username":"Elliot Scher","primary_group_name":null,"flair_name":null,"flair_url":null,"flair_bg_color":null,"flair_color":null,"flair_group_id":null,"badges_granted":[],"version":2,"can_edit":false,"can_delete":false,"can_recover":false,"can_see_hidden_post":true,"can_wiki":false,"read":true,"user_title":"","reply_to_user":{"id":44380,"username":"gdefender","name":"Andy Gasser","avatar_template":"/user_avatar/www.chiefdelphi.com/gdefender/{size}/168507_2.png"},"bookmarked":false,"actions_summary":[],"moderator":false,"admin":false,"staff":false,"user_id":49423,"hidden":false,"trust_level":2,"deleted_at":null,"user_deleted":false,"edit_reason":null,"can_view_edit_history":true,"wiki":false,"user_custom_fields":{"user_field_4":"2815A (19-23) | 190M (23...)"},"post_url":"/t/has-anyone-had-any-luck-with-turning-in-a-pathweaver-autonomous-with-adis16470/430262/3","custom_user_title":"2815A (19-23) | 190M (23...)","reactions":[],"current_user_reaction":null,"reaction_users_count":0,"current_user_used_main_reaction":false,"can_accept_answer":false,"can_unaccept_answer":false,"accepted_answer":false,"topic_accepted_answer":null},{"id":3165255,"name":"Andy Gasser","username":"gdefender","avatar_template":"/user_avatar/www.chiefdelphi.com/gdefender/{size}/168507_2.png","created_at":"2023-03-15T14:35:31.680Z","cooked":"
Gandagorn:

for the getHeading() method, the IMU is CCW positive so negating it allows the value to increase as it turns clockwise

CCW positive is the correct rotation, you should not be negating it. See the note on the Differential Drive Odometry documentation page:

0 degrees / radians represents the robot angle when the robot is facing directly toward your opponent’s alliance station. As your robot turns to the left, your gyroscope angle should increase.

Gandagorn:

Modding it by 360 makes sure that the robot is always at an angle between 0 and 360.

The angle should be a value between -180 and 180. This one is a little hidden in the documentation, but it’s mentioned in the java doc in the sample code on Step 3 of the Trajectory Tutorial:

/**
 * Returns the heading of the robot.
 *
 * @return the robot's heading in degrees, from -180 to 180
 */

This can be handled with Math.IEEEremainder.

    Math.IEEEremainder(gyro.getAngle(), 360.0d);
Gandagorn:

Our roborio is mounted vertically so the yaw axis is actually the pitch axis.

Your getHeading() method is returning the gyro yaw, which you said is not your robot yaw. I recommend setting the Yaw access in the ADIS16470_IMU constructor, or calling setYawAxis() so it’s less confusing.
